instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
This board has green light

0 volt on fuse F7040
Diode mode on fuse 0.083

When I Remove F7040 I get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at pin 1 of F7040 so short is after fuse

What should I try first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I don't have a similar board to meassure on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check for a short from PPBUS to any of the coils to rule out a shorted high side FET. After that you can inject a few volt to see what heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I'm not really sure what coils I should check. Is it F7415 and F7425? And how to check short.
I tried to remove F7025, diode mode on fuse changed from 0,083 to 0,144

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Other coils means the coil at the end of <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, etc. Other power lines that are derived from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. In terms of how to check a short, multimeter, continuity mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I wrote wrong letters in previous post

When I remove L7025 diode mode on fuse F7040 changed from 0,083 to 0,144


Resistance to groud
L7630 21 ohm   (<SIGNAL>PPCPUVTT_S0_REG_R</SIGNAL>)
L7330 3.5 K       (<SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG_R</SIGNAL>
L7530 79 ohm   (<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GFX_REG_R</SIGNAL>)
L8920 7 ohm     (<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU_REG_R</SIGNAL>)
L7220 23 K       (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>)
L7260 5.7 K      (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>)
L7425 57 ohm   (<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>)
L7415 58 ohm   (<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: what duke was asking was resistance of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to those coils of those power supplies. If there is no low resistance from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to those coils, put 1 volt in with a DC power supply on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and slowly raise it until something gets warm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Resistance to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

L7630 52 ohm (<SIGNAL>PPCPUVTT_S0_REG_R</SIGNAL>)
L7330 6 M (<SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG_R</SIGNAL>
L7530 114 ohm (<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GFX_REG_R</SIGNAL>)
L8920 67 ohm (<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU_REG_R</SIGNAL>)
L7220 4.6 K (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>)
L7260 0.83 K (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Seems ok to inject voltage on PPBUS. Start off with 1 volt and see if anything heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok. I don't have a lab power supply. Looked at the old video with Louis where he uses a atx power supply and the led strips in the window. Started with 5 v, nothing. Tried 12 volt and still nothing burning. Checked with my fingers and with alcohol. Am I doing something wrong?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What is resistance to GND on PPBUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Resistance to ground on ppbus is 67 ohm. I don't have F7040 soldered back yet so I'm messuring after the fuse. 
I belive everything is ok before the fuse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 67 is a bit high so there will not be a lot of heat generated. Make sure to use a power supply that doesn't shut down when connected. Use your lips to feel the board
